segment.source: Enumerate devices over a network
segment.target: Enumerate devices over a network

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: Windows.Devices.Enumeration
segment.target: Windows.Devices.Enumeration

segment.source: In addition to discovering locally connected devices, you can use the Windows.Devices.Enumeration APIs to enumerate devices over wireless and networked protocols.
segment.target: In addition to discovering locally connected devices, you can use the Windows.Devices.Enumeration APIs to enumerate devices over wireless and networked protocols.

segment.source: Enumerating devices over networked or wireless protocols
segment.target: Enumerating devices over networked or wireless protocols

segment.source: Sometimes you need to enumerate devices that are not locally connected and can only be discovered over a wireless or networking protocols.
segment.target: Sometimes you need to enumerate devices that are not locally connected and can only be discovered over a wireless or networking protocols.

segment.source: In order to do so, the Windows.Devices.Enumeration APIs have three different kinds of device objects: the AssociationEndpoint (AEP), the AssociationEndpointContainer (AEP Container), and the AssociationEndpointService (AEP Service).
segment.target: In order to do so, the Windows.Devices.Enumeration APIs have three different kinds of device objects: the AssociationEndpoint (AEP), the AssociationEndpointContainer (AEP Container), and the AssociationEndpointService (AEP Service).

segment.source: As a group these are referred to as AEPs or AEP objects.
segment.target: As a group these are referred to as AEPs or AEP objects.

segment.source: Some device APIs provide a selector string that you can use to enumerate through the available AEP objects.
segment.target: Some device APIs provide a selector string that you can use to enumerate through the available AEP objects.

segment.source: This could include both devices that are paired and are not paired with the system.
segment.target: This could include both devices that are paired and are not paired with the system.

segment.source: Some of the devices might not require pairing.
segment.target: Some of the devices might not require pairing.

segment.source: Those device APIs may attempt to pair the device if pairing it is necessary before interacting with it.
segment.target: Those device APIs may attempt to pair the device if pairing it is necessary before interacting with it.

segment.source: Wi-Fi Direct is an example of APIs that follow this pattern.
segment.target: Wi-Fi Direct is an example of APIs that follow this pattern.

segment.source: If those device APIs do not automatically pair the device, you can pair it using the DeviceInformationPairing object available from DeviceInformation.Pairing.
segment.target: If those device APIs do not automatically pair the device, you can pair it using the DeviceInformationPairing object available from DeviceInformation.Pairing.

segment.source: However, there may be cases where you want to manually discover devices on your own without using a pre-defined selector string.
segment.target: However, there may be cases where you want to manually discover devices on your own without using a pre-defined selector string.

segment.source: For example, you may just need to gather information about AEP devices without interacting with them or you may want to find more AEP objects than will be discovered with the pre-defined selector string.
segment.target: For example, you may just need to gather information about AEP devices without interacting with them or you may want to find more AEP objects than will be discovered with the pre-defined selector string.

segment.source: In this case, you will build your own selector string and use it following the instructions under Build a device selector.
segment.target: In this case, you will build your own selector string and use it following the instructions under Build a device selector.

segment.source: When you build your own selector, it is strongly recommended that you limit your scope of enumeration to the protocols that you are interested in.
segment.target: When you build your own selector, it is strongly recommended that you limit your scope of enumeration to the protocols that you are interested in.

segment.source: For example, you don't want to have the Wi-Fi radio search for Wi-Fi Direct devices if you are particularly interested in UPnP devices.
segment.target: For example, you don't want to have the Wi-Fi radio search for Wi-Fi Direct devices if you are particularly interested in UPnP devices.

segment.source: Windows has defined an identity for each protocol that you can use to scope your enumeration.
segment.target: Windows has defined an identity for each protocol that you can use to scope your enumeration.

segment.source: The following table lists the protocol types and identifiers.
segment.target: The following table lists the protocol types and identifiers.

segment.source: Protocol or network device type
segment.target: Protocol or network device type

segment.source: Id
segment.target: Id

segment.source: UPnP (including DIAL and DLNA)
segment.target: UPnP (including DIAL and DLNA)

segment.target: Web services on devices (WSD)

segment.source: Wi-Fi Direct
segment.target: Wi-Fi Direct

segment.target: DNS service discovery (DNS-SD)

segment.target: Point of service

segment.target: Network printers (active directory printers)

segment.target: Windows connect now (WNC)

segment.target: WiGig docks

segment.target: Wi-Fi provisioning for HP printers

segment.source: AQS examples
segment.target: AQS examples

segment.source: Each AEP kind has a property you can use to constrain your enumeration to a specific protocol.
segment.target: Each AEP kind has a property you can use to constrain your enumeration to a specific protocol.

segment.source: Keep in mind you can use the OR operator in an AQS filter to combine multiple protocols.
segment.target: Keep in mind you can use the OR operator in an AQS filter to combine multiple protocols.

segment.source: Here are some examples of AQS filter strings that show how to query for AEP devices.
segment.target: Here are some examples of AQS filter strings that show how to query for AEP devices.

segment.source: This AQS queries for all UPnP AssociationEndpoint objects when the DeviceInformationKind is set to AsssociationEndpoint.
segment.target: This AQS queries for all UPnP AssociationEndpoint objects when the DeviceInformationKind is set to AsssociationEndpoint.

segment.source: This AQS queries for all UPnP and WSD AssociationEndpoint objects when the DeviceInformationKind is set to AsssociationEndpoint.
segment.target: This AQS queries for all UPnP and WSD AssociationEndpoint objects when the DeviceInformationKind is set to AsssociationEndpoint.

segment.source: This AQS queries for all UPnP AssociationEndpointService objects if the DeviceInformationKind is set to AsssociationEndpointService.
segment.target: This AQS queries for all UPnP AssociationEndpointService objects if the DeviceInformationKind is set to AsssociationEndpointService.

segment.source: This AQS queries AssociationEndpointContainer objects when the DeviceInformationKind is set to AssociationEndpointContainer, but only finds them by enumerating the UPnP protocol.
segment.target: This AQS queries AssociationEndpointContainer objects when the DeviceInformationKind is set to AssociationEndpointContainer, but only finds them by enumerating the UPnP protocol.

segment.source: Typically, it wouldn't be useful to enumerate containers that only come from one protocol.
segment.target: Typically, it wouldn't be useful to enumerate containers that only come from one protocol.

segment.source: However, this might be useful by limiting your filter to protocols where you know your device can be discovered.
segment.target: However, this might be useful by limiting your filter to protocols where you know your device can be discovered.
